But the interview process that I typically prescribe to most HR organizations that you'll typically encouter that you'll dercibe to are three part. We ask what attracts you to the company, what makes you think the company is a great fit for you? Then we ask how you think your education and experience relate to the job. The employer is looking to find out not your whole work life history. They want to know if you have the skills that they need for that job and then they'll need to know a little bit more about your leadership and team work. Sometimes there's those fluffy behavioral questions. I don't do that, I just ask. Um, and then they give you time to ask questions about the company to make sure it's the best fit for you and then they give you that moment, that  moment for that elevator pitch. Everything we do is beneath that pillar. And the way that we approach that is that we have technical training which you abolutely need and require like certifications and your basic how-to's, and then that is all taken care of within our training program, we also do have external  acollegent relationships for that. We also have tuition assistance if that's something you want to do out on top of it, we also have the requried training that the government makes you do like ethics, cybersecurity all those things and we also believe in personal and professional development, so we use DISK surverys to make sure that your temperment is one way or another and you can aquire some skills that maybe you don't have, but maybe use your natural inclinations as a team member, we also have something we consider sommunication series, which we teach people how to talk to each other, we have supervisor series, which means if you get promoted you take one year to complete a cohort of courses that teach you how to be a supervisor within this coompany, we have leadership series.
